metadata.title: The Leadership Breakfast
metadata.time_reference: During the Administration of President Bartlet

releases.details: The complete Season 2 was released including The Leadership Breakfast.

notes: This is the last episode to air during the Clinton administration.
Karen Cahill is based on the real New York Times columnist Maureen Dowd, who dated Aaron Sorkin.

real_world_cultural_references: References to the New York Times and political journalists.

continuity_notes: The fireplace in the Mural Room was noted to have been welded shut for over 100 years.

plot.plot_summary: As a bipartisan breakfast approaches, tensions rise among President Bartlet's staff regarding the arrangement and topics of discussion, including introducing a patient's bill of rights. C.J. clashes with Ann Stark, the House Majority Leader's chief of staff, while Leo and Josh address an insult directed towards a powerful news columnist. A series of mishaps, including Sam and Josh creating a smoke emergency in preparation for the breakfast, set the stage for political maneuvering and miscommunication that culminate in a chaotic press conference.
